I did both. In my 40's, I rode my bicycle 1,500, 2,000 and 2,000 miles over a three summer period. I went from 232 pounds at 43 years old to 204 pounds at 45 years old. That was a hell of a lot of exercise, and it took me three years to lose 28 pounds.
At 55 years old, I started eating a carnivore diet most of the time. I went from 232 pounds in the summer of 2019 to 209 pounds today. I lost 23 pounds in a year and a half by diet with very little exercise, and I am ten years older. It took me just over a year to lose that weight, and I didn't always stick to the diet.
I used to think exercise was more important, but through trial and error I realize that a good ketogenic diet took off the weight with a lot less effort.
Diet is better for weight loss than exercise because you have to exercise a hell of a lot like I did to lose any real weight.

Simple common sense, huh? I can attest to this approach: in December, 2016, I weighed 249 lbs.; in December, 2017, 211 lbs; on June 28, 2018, I weighed 188 lbs.
A year out of high school ('69) I was at 258 lbs. and never looked back. The difference now? I have cut down on my calorie intake, pure and simple.
My excellent brother Ray shared an image with me several years ago that made sense. He told me to make a fist and said that my stomach was actually about that size. If I eat more than that at any one time, I'm overeating.
This was my epiphany. That easy truth provided me a path for portion control. When I'm hungry, I eat, whatever I want, until I feel full. The portions are now much abbreviated, and the quality of my diet has improved. I do not 'diet', what with the pointlessness of most. I just eat less.
The weight loss has pleased my physician; my labs are all satisfactory. And did I mention I am close to ending my need for injecting insulin? Huh. Go figure!

I can tell that in some cases, exercising regularly is easier than going on a diet. Plus, it's pretty hard for mostly people to keep on a diet for more than 1-2 months without going insane! I workout 4-5 times per week (mostly weightlifting), and I feel hungry as a lion sometimes, the plan that was given to me, and was already adjusted... well, I still feel hungry if I only eat the amount of food it says there, and I don't feel I'm getting enough energy to do such physical efforts nor through the rest of the day, even eating what's supposed for me to eat. It's just not enough! So I added a little bit more food to some of my meals recently and I feel with more energy while at the gym. Your body can still suffer good changes without having to be hungry...  I would just say that if you do some adjustments in what you eat daily (eat more of the good stuff and less of what's not that good, but really without having to deprive yourself to the limit - because deprivation may have bad consequences at short/long-term - eating disorders are pretty awful), and you'll start noticing a few differences on you through the time, and surely practising exercise will definitely help you on that and making you feeling healthier and younger as well. You can still make progress without dieting, even though it will be slower in some cases, but not impossible. But don't expect to have great results by working out alone and not changing your eating habits... That does not work well. Don't add sugar to your coffee or eat out everyday, and put some salad in that sandwich...  If you're aiming ONLY for weight loss, probably you need to be even more careful with your eating habits, nothing comes alone of course... But "Diet" is something I don't like to hear nor talk about, it's not good to keep at it for a long time. Stopping it will have worst consequences than stopping working out for a few weeks. Muscle takes longer to build, and takes longer to go away too, plus, helps burning more calories too. Diets can make you thinner at short term, but you can't expect not to gain fat once you stop dieting for some time. A nutrition plan is more effective than diets, though, can be a bit hard to follow sometimes, it gets boring, but, adjust it to your needs and that may become a natural routine.

Changing one’s diet is the most tried and true way to help a person lose weight, but it is more difficult than it sounds. If for years you have chosen to eat certain things that you enjoy and then you suddenly decide to cut all of that out, it is going to cause drastic differences in many aspects of your life. It may drastically change what you look like on the outside if you chose to only eat things that are good for your body but it is also going to change a lot about you. When you first begin your diet it may make you cranky or agitated that you cannot have the things that your body is craving but once your body is used to only having things that are good for it, you will begin to feel the benefits it is doing for you. Diets are hard but they will change your life for the better.

I completely agree with the fact that diet and nutrition play a slightly larger role in weight loss. In addition to seeing results faster, if you have proper nutrition, you are less likely to put the weight on to begin with. Yes, while exercise can help reduce the risk for many types of diseases, so can proper nutrition. Now, I'm not saying that everything we put into our bodies has to be super healthy, it is okay to indulge once and awhile, however, we should be incorporating more healthy meal choices into our diets daily.

Okay guys, I'm gonna share a little secret about losing weight. I lost 20 pounds (and am continuing to lose) with NO EXERCISE at all. No early morning jogs or long days at the gym. I realized that it's all about WATCHING WHAT YOU EAT. Before, I loved to eat greasy foods like from McDonalds and stuff or tons of pastries. I didn't give a second thought to what I was eating or how much of it. However, once I started to actually pay attention to the kinds of foods I ate and how much of it (by keeping a little journal), I realized that I was overeating waaaaaay to much. It really helps if you keep a little log of what you're eating every day. You don't even need to know how many calories are in each food; just making a mental note of what you have already ate already helps. The key to losing weight really is watching what you eat. There are really simple calculators online that can tell you how many calories you should eat a day. Then, all you do is eat less than that. Simple. Sure, it's waaay better to eat healthy foods but as long as you consume less calories than you need to maintain your weight every day, you're on the right track to losing weight. Just a helpful tip for you guys who are serious about wanting to lose some weight. Btw I've been dieting for around two months now, so don't expect the weight to melt off, but if you make the right choices every day it will WORK. Please upvote if this helped you, so others can see this comment to. :)

I think this video neglected to point out another thing about exercise vs. diet change. While both are essential to a healthy body, if you're strictly trying to lose weight, diet change is definitely more important than rigorous exercise. Why? Because exercise strengthens muscles, which contributes to a gain in muscle mass, which means that, while the weight is certainly healthy, you still gain some from more muscle.

a big confounding factor that was seriously overlooked in this episode is what happens to your body over time with diet alone. muscle atrophy, decreased metabolism, immunodeficiency. You should get about eighty percent of your 500-1000 calorie deficit from diet and about twenty percent from exercise to prevent the drawbacks of dieting.

I feel that exercise is more important. Here is my reasoning. I found that I eat healthier when I exercise. Exercise makes my body seems to crave healthier foods. If I don't exercise and try to eat healthy I seem to always fail. Though eating healthier is the determining factor for losing the weight, the only way I am actually able to make myself eat healthy is by exercising in the first place. Diet might be important but it is much harder to maintain a proper diet without exercise.

It's not that hard. Eat well and exercise 5x a week, 30 min a pop and you SHOULD maintain your weight. I had a malfunctioning thyroid for a few years in my late 20s due to cancer, and I had to exercise in pretty intense amounts, but I still maintained my weight. Even after my thyroid started working right again, I love exercising. I've always been athletic and never had a single regret about that. Exercise improves your heart and lungs, releases endorphins, and gives you muscle tone. Diet alone won't do that.

The really interesting thing is that we've recently found that epigenetic markers related to appetite control are found in sperm, and they change if the man goes through weight loss surgery. We also suspect mothers pass their epigenetic markers down to their children. So if your parents were over-eating when they conceived you, then you're more likely to over-eat. I wouldn't be surprised if this effect is amplifying the obesity epidemic in the developed world.

Also consider that in the developed world, we tend to have children when we're older, and you also tend to get fatter as you get older.

You can't offer a definitive answer on this argument because each side has support, it all depends on context, you can just as easily prove exercise is more important, with a blend of both being the best. Pretty straightforward. Plenty of workout nuts or former/current athletes could show you they can eat like shit and still be under 10% bodyfat and at a healthy weight. They are shoveling down empty calories just so they don't lose muscle. If you don't have muscle you are fat. Weight loss isn't the same as fat loss. Sustained habits that keep you healthy are different then short term calorie restrictions that provide number results, but aren't sustainable lifelong. The same amount of "calories" in one food plan vs. another also can have wildly different effects on how those calories are processed in the body. The same time dedicated to exercise in one person vs another can also have wildly different effects on how that body is being built based on the type of exercise.

These are some of the many examples of why specific context is required anytime one of these "studies" makes a claim.
If you do the right kind of physical activity, you can definitely out exercise a poor diet. People do it everyday. Heck I did 6 for $10 pizzas and 6 boxes for $4 mac and cheese and drank 40 beers a week only taking a multivitamin in college for 5 years all while at 9% bodyfat, and passed every health and blood assessment with flying colors. Consistent intense exercise is the only possible reason why I was able to do that. Interval strength speed and power training has been that solution for many people for ever. This is what our ancestors did as they had to perform manual labor all day just to survive. Unless you have a certain serious medical condition, If you can't do basic bodyweight exercises or squat/deadlift/carry well beyond your bodyweight and move through full ranges of motion, you have no excuse why your metabolism sucks so bad. If your version of exercise is steady state repetitive jogging or elliptical, you are also probably doing some of the worst versions of exercise that there is.

The greatest predictors of longevity are all exercise and movement related, #1 Leg Strength, #2 V02 Max, #3 Muscle mass.
Stop restricting calories, eat to help your body perform better through movement. Our grandparents aren't struggling to get up and move because they ate some junk food in their life, they are struggling to move because their hips and back are so weak and out of alignment from inactivity and weakness which in turn makes their heart work harder to support their weak bodies, their brains are degenerating because they never stimulate their body and mind through movement.

The health problems in this world will never diminish as long as people continue to neglect life long well balanced movement and fitness.

I just can't like this video. They name it "exercise vs diet" then all they talk about is activity. They are not the same. Exercising is actively doing something to push your body more than you would during normal activity to improve muscle mass or efficiency. So an office worker walking to work is being active, but getting off work and hitting the gym is different. At the end of the day exercise generates muscle and will burn fat more easily, activity simply burns fat and doesn't push your muscles to grow or increase in density.

There's or course a gray area between them, but someone power walking, another jogging, and another running will NOT have the same muscle mass and will NOT burn fat at the same rate, regardless of diet. I'm not saying diet doesn't play a part in it, but habits are a bigger part. You should not habitually eat junk food and exercise to compensate nor should you eat salads and sit all day.

Losing weight is much more than calories in versus calories out. If you eat 100 calories of sugar it will react in your body a lot differently than 100 calories of fat or protein, mainly because carbohydrates cause an insulin release (the fat storing hormone) whereas fat and protein do not (or very minimal.) And the more insulin that is floating around in your bloodstream, the less glucagen (fat burning hormone) you have. So if you want to lose weight you need to increase your glucagon levels and you do that by minimizing your insulin levels. It has been proven that those on a ketogenic diet (consuming under 20g of carbs per day) lose significantly more body fat than those on a low-fat, high carb diet despite the same caloric intake and exercise levels.

!!!

Go vegan, go pizza-free, go soft drink-free, do whatever... but for the love of god please don't go carb-free.

For those of you looking to make that change, pick one thing that you are going to absolutely commit to no matter what. Something simple E.g. Drink more water, go for a walk in the morning etc. Do that every day  for 3 weeks and once it begins a habit, add something else on top of that new habit for 3 weeks and repeat the process. Making sweeping changes all at once rarely works long term as we have a finite amount of will power.

I started calorie counting a few months ago and since then I've gone from 72kg to 68kg and still dropping. In that time frame I've had plenty of chocolate, pizza, fries, burgers, soft drink, you name it: I just note down how many calories each thing I eat or drink contains and make sure I never go above my daily limit.

Granted, eating a mcdonalds every day is hardly going to be healthy, but health and weight loss are not necessarily the same thing. So there you have it

This is true, but like, a good reason most of America is obese is because most of America can't afford those healthy salads and organic and unprocessed fruits and veggies.
When you're on a tight budget, you'd much rather spend $1 on an entire meal with all the calories you need over a $5 apple which will only give you a handful.

If we somehow found ways to make the production of fruits and vegetables cheaper than fast foods (without damaging the economy in other ways, such as laying off thousands of workers to replace them with robotic fruitpickers), I would be really surprised if the obesity rate didn't go down.

But at the same time, like, being fat doesn't inherently hurt you. It can make some stuff a pain, and it can be a warning for other, more serious and actually dangerous problems, but if you're active, eat well, don't have cholesterol problems or blood pressure problems, being fat isn't bad for you on its own.

Promote health, not thinness.

When it comes purely to weight loss, its only a matter of your diet. And not even WHAT you eat, just your caloric intake. For pure weight loss, it doesn't matter if you eat 200 calories worth of chocolate or 200 calories worth of salad. If you pay attention to calories, you can lose weight eating nothing but junk food. However, when you consider health, its completely different. While you can lose weight without exercise, you won't be healthy. While you can lose weight while only eating Oreos, it doesn't make it healthy. Weight loss is not health. In terms of being healthy, exercise has a much bigger effect, from what I've learned. Even weighing 250 lbs, you can be relatively healthy if you exercise enough, even if you don't do enough exercise to lose weight. Once again, weight loss does not equate to being healthy.

As someone who lost 100 lbs, its all about the deficit. Exercise increases that deficit. You have your maintenence calories, which keep you where you are at (assuming your level of activity is static). Eating in a healthy way so that you eat less than you use while still consuming the fats, proteins, vitamins, etc. will allow healthy weight loss. Exercising will negate even more calories. However, exercise is more than uust burning calories. Muscle requires excess calories (above your maintenence calories) to build, but it will never build without working the muscles out. Also exercise also benefits your mental health, and it is a healthy way with dealing with stress. So if you want to lose weight, go on a diet. If you want to change your life, exercise and diet.

For those struggling to gain weight. (Me included).
Eat more than you burn.

Calculate your Basal Metabolic Rate.
Basal Metabolic Rate = 10 x weight (kg) + 6.25 x height (cm) - 5 x age (years) + 5.
The number you get is how many calories you burn off by doing NOTHING. That means sitting, not doing anything for 24 hours.


Then (x) your number by how much exercise you do.
1.0 = None.
1.1 = Light.
1.2 = Semi.
1.3 = Moderate.
1.4 High. (Physical Job).
1.5 = Highest form. (Physical Job)

Aim for at least 2.2 x weight (kg) of protein every day.
Example.
70 x 2.2 = 154 grams.

Actually losing weight is not exclusively about calorie intake, but also metabolism.

The problem with reducing calorie intake, is that it also reduces your metabolism. So basically if you naturally burn 2000 calories a day, you have to consume, say 1800 calories a day, consistently, to lose meaningful weight.

The problem is that eventually you don't burn 2000 calories naturally, you start burning only 1900-1800 cals. So you're still eating less than usual, feeling hungry, low on energy, and not even losing weight.

Best thing is to eat the 2000 calories you need, or even a little more (just don't eat 4000 calories a day). But exercise 45 mins, or 1 hour.
Then you're not only losing weight, you increase metabolism, and naturally burn more calories. Even if you stop exercising you'll still burn more calories than usual for months.

Moderation is key. If you're in a hurry to lose weight and you exercise too much, for too long, your body can't keep up, you'll experience over-training. This means your body can't take it anymore, you'll lose muscle mass, metabolism, and you'll feel terrible. So it's very important to rest, to maintain good metabolism.

Long story short... shortest way is not always the best way.

I was overweight and managed to lose ~30 lbs in about 2 months with a combination of excercise and diet. What I found were the most helpful things I did were: 1) not worrying about looks but instead focusing on being healthy and happy and 2) reducing the portions of food I ate... There is no miracle diet and there is no need to radically change what you like to eat, the trick is reducing caloric intake (caloric input - caloric output=excess calories, which accumulate as fats)... keep it simple. Use smaller plates at first and naturally you'll start worrying about the nutritional qualities of what you're eating.

Well.. that's just not true. Your body adapts both physically and hormonally. This means that when a lazy person (with no change to their diet) weighing 200 lbs that has not run a day in their lives, gets up and walks for 30 minutes, they might burn 200 calories that first time, but after about two weeks, their body adapts. Now weighing 195 lbs that same person is only burning 170 calories.
Let's say that this lazy person maintains this 30 minute walk for a year. At about 185 lbs or so the person's weight plateaus. Within 2 years, bam! Back up to 200 lbs.
Now, if we tinker slightly with this person's hormonal balance, by adding additional testosterone.. say 20 times what the person's body normally produces, and started again, what do you suppose would happen? Within 2 weeks down to 190. Within a month, down to 180. Then we adjust the hormonal balance again (because the body is adapting) and add 35 times the normal amount of testosterone. Within another month down to 170. Cycling off the testosterone, and adding another 30 minute walk, up to 175 in 2 weeks. Why do you think this is happening?
Your body is a chemical stew. Hormones regulate everything. If you want to drop weight, and you have tried a few things and nothing works, consult an endocrinologist!

This leaves out a lot of important factors. Reducing calories under maintenance level  is the easiest way to lose WEIGHT, but do you really want to lose weight or do you want to lose FAT? If the latter is your answer, you are probably better off doing some kind of resistance training (i.e. Lifting weights or bodyweight training) otherwise your body will break down the protein in your muscles and use them as an energy source ( since our body can't store protein it's also important to have an adequate protein intake). I could go on and on but I think I've made the point clear enough: if you only reduce your caloric intake you'll lose weight (both fat and lean mass) and you will still look like sh*t at the end of your diet. Not to mention that most people would rather move around and exercise and still being able to eat some (note some, not crazy amounts) foods like ice cream, pizza etc than starve themselves to death.
